article.headline: Rutgers 78, Buffalo 53
article.story: PISCATAWAY, N.J. (AP) -- With a trip to No. 15 Wisconsin looming on Saturday, Rutgers needed a good effort to serve as a send-off. The Knights got just that in the second half Tuesday night, as Ricky Shields scored 22 points and Herve Lamizana had 11 of his 15 after intermission to fuel Rutgers to a 78-53 victory over Buffalo. Rutgers (2-0) used an 18-4 run early in the second half to bury Buffalo (0-2) and send the Bulls to their 23rd straight defeat on the road. "It's a good thing we got a solid second half, but now we're going to another level," forward Sean Axani said. "They're 15th in the country, they're playing at home. They'll be in their comfort zone." Much like Axani has been in his own zone early this season. The fifth-year senior had 10 points, 12 rebounds, six assists, five blocked shots and five steals against the Bulls. "He feels comfortable out there now, and he feels needed," Rutgers coach Gary Waters said. "For three years everyone else was taking all the life out of everything and he didn't feel a chance to be needed." "I've been here a long time and logged a lot of minutes," Axani said. "I feel comfortable now and I'm trying to help other guys feel comfortable out there." After a sub-par opening night due to illness, Shields looked comfortable in shooting 8-for-10 and 2-for-3 from 3-point range. He also had eight rebounds. Lamizana had four blocked shots, while Adrian Hill had 13 points. Buffalo, which committed 21 turnovers after committing 25 in its opener against Canisius, got 13 points from B.J. Walker. The Bulls shot just 27.5 percent. With Rutgers holding a 41-32 lead, Hill scored inside to start the Scarlet Knights' run. Rutgers made nine of its first 11 shots in the half to open a 59-36 lead, and Buffalo never got closer than 14. Lamizana had seven points in the run while Shields added 11. "It was big to play like this," Shields said. "It gives you a lot of confidence and gives you some momentum going into Wisconsin. And it was real big for Herve to get out there and get his flow going, because we're going to need him." The Knights had two 25-point leads including the final score. Waters is 7-0 against Buffalo, including six wins when he coached at Kent State. Rutgers made seven of its first 11 shots in taking a 14-4 lead and maintained its advantage throughout the first half. Buffalo cut it to 31-27 before an 8-2 run helped Rutgers regain its 10-point margin at halftime. Buffalo shot 36.7 percent in the half with 14 turnovers. Shields and Hill combined for 25 points in the half. Rutgers will now attempt to beat a ranked team for the seventh time in its two-plus seasons under Waters. "I think this gives us an opportunity to go out there and make a statement," Lamizana said. "Then come back home, take care of business and get ready for the Big East. I'm not saying we're going to win, but I feel confident about what we'll do out there."
